items.title:
Survival of the fittest code.

Core War (1984) is a game where programs must crash their opponents t...
items.content:
Survival of the fittest code.

Core War (1984) is a game where programs must crash their opponents to survive. Warriors written in an assembly language called Redcode fight for control of a virtual machine.

Our new paper: Digital Red Queen: Adversarial Program Evolution in Core War with LLMs, explores what happens when LLMs drive an adversarial evolutionary arms race in this domain.

We task LLMs to write Warrior programs in Redcode that must out-compete a virtual world full of such programs. Core War is a Turing-complete environment where code and data share the same address space, which leads to some very chaotic self-modifying code dynamics.

This approach is inspired by the Red Queen hypothesis in evolutionary biology: the principle that species must continually adapt and evolve simply to survive against ever changing competitors. In our work, programs continuously adapt to defeat a growing history of opponents rather than a static benchmark.

We find that this adversarial process leads to the emergence of increasingly general strategies, including targeted self-replication, data bombing, and massive multithreading. Most intriguingly, it reveals a form of convergent evolution. Different code implementations settle into similar high performing behaviors, mirroring how biological agents independently evolve similar traits to solve the same problems.

I think this work positions Core War as a sandbox for studying Red Queen dynamics in artificial systems. It offers a safe controlled environment for analyzing how AI agents might evolve in real world adversarial settings such as cybersecurity.

By simulating these adversarial dynamics in an isolated sandbox, we offer a glimpse into the future where deployed LLM systems may start competing against one another for limited resources in the real world.
items.author: @hardmaru
items.summary: Google DeepMind's David Ha presents major research on 'Digital Red Queen' - LLMs driving adversarial evolutionary arms race in Core War. Programs evolve strategies like self-replication, data bombing, and multithreading. Shows convergent evolution patterns and implications for AI safety in adversarial settings.
items.reasoning: Very high engagement (160K+ views, 2200+ likes), novel research from credible researcher, original insights on LLM-driven evolution with safety implications, detailed technical content

items.title:
@andrew_n_carr Yeah, $10B is the difference in finding it first and ~5 years ago. :)

I just love re...
items.content:
@andrew_n_carr Yeah, $10B is the difference in finding it first and ~5 years ago. :)

I just love reproducing landmark results for much cheaper, it's so fun!

Reproducing LeCun 1989 was super fun too:
https://t.co/oOZcQW3Y9H
What runs unoptimized on a consumer laptop in 1 minute was a state of the art neural net trained for days in 1989.

Another favorite example: CIFAR-10. In 2011 state of the art was 77%. I estimated human accuracy to be ~94% but said that performance might go up to 85-90%.
https://t.co/KJl0V4T0ei
Now you can speedrun to 94% accuracy in 1.98 seconds on a single GPU (yes, <2 seconds).
https://t.co/wHUQs6htdV

So e.g. right now GPT-2 (imo the landmark result that launched LLMs and where the modern stack is basically in full form) is ~$500, but I'm unreasonably obsessed with how much that can be brought down.
items.author: @karpathy
items.summary: As discussed in [Social](/?date=2026-01-08&category=social#item-0c0e4b913023) yesterday Karpathy discusses the dramatic cost reduction in reproducing landmark ML results - LeCun 1989, CIFAR-10, and GPT-2 now trainable for ~$500. Reflects on how state-of-the-art from decades ago now runs in seconds on consumer hardware.

items.title: I like and bookmark so many interesting sounding papers here, and don‚Äôt get back to most of them. Ti...
items.content:
I like and bookmark so many interesting sounding papers here, and don‚Äôt get back to most of them. Time to start making a dent. I‚Äôm going to try to at least skim one of the papers in my bookmarks each weekday for the rest of the month.

#PaperADay

2025: Emergent temporal abstractions in autoregressive models enable hierarchical reinforcement learning (Google)

I like their statement of the hierarchical goal problem¬† as ‚Äúhow long does it take a twitching hand to win a game of chess?‚Äù¬† @RichardSSutton is fond of the ‚Äúoptions‚Äù framework in RL, but we don‚Äôt have a clear method to learn them from scratch.

Their Ant environment is designed to require two levels of planning: the standard mujoco Ant locomotion work to be able to move at all, and routing decisions to get to the colored squares in the correct order, which will happen hundreds of frames apart.

Basically, this takes a pre-trained sequence predicting model that predicts what separately trained expert models (manually steered) do, and inserts a metacontroller midway through it, which can tweak the residual values to perform high level ‚Äústeering‚Äù, and can be RL‚Äôd at high level switch points to much greater performance than the base pre-trained model.

A key claim here is that learning to predict actions in a supervised next-token manner from lots of existing expert examples, even if you don‚Äôt know the goals, results in inferring useful higher level goals. This sounds plausible, but their experiment makes it rather easy for the model: the expert RL models that generated the training data were explicitly given one of four goals in each segment, and the option learning model just classifies the sequences into one of four categories. This is a vastly simpler problem than free form option discovery.

A State Space Model is used for the more complex Ant environments, while a transformer is used for the simpler grid world environments. I didn‚Äôt see an explanation for the change.

The internal ‚Äúwalls‚Äù are more like ‚Äúpoison tiles‚Äù, since they don‚Äôt block movement like the map edges, they just kill the ant when its center passes into them.

The 3D renderings (with shadow errors that hurt my gamedev eyes) are somewhat misleading, since it is really a 2D world that the agent gets to fully observe in a low dimensional one-hot format. It doesn‚Äôt do any kind of partially observed or pixel based sensing.

Everything is done with massively parallel environments, avoiding the harder online learning challenges.

The success rates still aren‚Äôt great after a million episodes.

I would like to see this applied to Atari, basically doing GATO with less capable experts or lower episode quantities, then trying to identify free form options that can be usefully used to RL to higher performance.
items.author: @ID_AA_Carmack
items.summary: John Carmack provides detailed #PaperADay review of Google's paper on hierarchical RL with emergent temporal abstractions. Analyzes the options framework, Ant environment design, and critiques including easy option discovery, unexplained architecture choices, and modest success rates. Suggests applying to Atari with GATO approach.
items.reasoning: Exceptional technical depth from legendary programmer. Original critical analysis of hierarchical RL research with specific insights on methodology, limitations, and future directions. Very high engagement (1099 likes, 93K views). Rare combination of credibility and substantive technical commentary.

items.title: If we let AI scrape our writing, code, images, and videos, blend them all, and sell them back to us,...
items.content:
If we let AI scrape our writing, code, images, and videos, blend them all, and sell them back to us, how are we going to make a living?

Who wants to keep feeding the AI for free?

Who wants to write and publish a project if AI will scrape it and regurgitate every line without returning traffic or attribution?

Despite AI's immense potential, there are many hard questions we need to answer.

items.content:
not actually surprising if you understand how coding agents is deployed at very large (>10k users per org) scale.*

dont be surprised that ai crossing the chasm means that not every coding agent user is a ‚Äúcracked‚Äù gen z mit dropout slinging CURRENT_THING (ralph/gastown/codex/goose/amp/whatever) in 12 parallel tmux sessions at once making $250k base fluent in the entire YC startup stack. the world is much much bigger than just SV, and the tech is only 1/2 the story in making IT useful/productive for actually everyone, not just the people who already talk and think like you.

the Devin is in the Details.

*ok it was a culture shock for me too but you see multiple 8figure deals ramp up >10k users per org again and again and you catch on real quick what a fucking giant revenue machine a scaled agent lab looks like

also theres plenty parallels for students of tech history - see how the system integrators embraced the shit out of the RPA boom. stuff like is is (admittedly with hindsight) only nonobvious if you (I included) were basically born yesterday as far as enterprise IT is concerned

items.title: @trevin Thank you. Factory is, in my opinion‚Äîand I'm slightly biased, but given the benchmarks‚Äîthe b...
items.content:
@trevin Thank you. Factory is, in my opinion‚Äîand I'm slightly biased, but given the benchmarks‚Äîthe best performing harness for an agent. It handles things that I don't need to think about, where I might need to think about them more if I'm using Claude Code or Codex or other tools. It can just get the job done better than I can get it done with other agents.

That's one thing. Another thing is that I don't need to think about: if I'm on Claude Code I can only use Claude models; if I'm on Codex I can only use OpenAI‚Äîswitch between them if I choose to‚Äîand if I want to use Gemini, I can use that as well, all in the same flow, all in the same session, all in the same projects, without really thinking about the different tools. It's just like the one tool that rules it all for me.

And then the VPS setup is I basically just set up a droplet on DigitalOcean and installed Droid there, and then I use something called Syncthing to sync certain repos from my machine, my local machine, to the VPS. And then two days ago I actually bought a Mac Mini, and then I've connected them all with Tailscale. So I actually have, then, when I'm offline‚Äîlike off my computer‚Äîthen I can use Slack to talk to Droid in a local or remote state. 

That's generally how I do it. I can go into more specifics if you'd like to do that.
items.author: @bentossell
items.summary: Ben Tossell explains his AI agent workflow: using Factory as best-performing agent harness, switching between Claude/OpenAI/Gemini models seamlessly, with VPS on DigitalOcean, Syncthing, Mac Mini, and Tailscale for remote Slack-based AI interaction.
items.reasoning: Detailed practical workflow from experienced builder showing sophisticated multi-model AI agent setup. Valuable implementation details.

items.title:
Nobody is going to post about automating boring tasks. But that's where the money is!

I know everyo...
items.content:
Nobody is going to post about automating boring tasks. But that's where the money is!

I know everyone is obsessed with building flashy demos because they look impressive, but they don't pay the bills.

Think about all the repetitive tasks a team does every day:

1. Running smoke tests after every deployment
2. Filling out forms across multiple systems
3. Checking that your checkout flow still works
4. Verifying login flows across browsers

All of these tasks eat up hours of developer time every single week. If you can cut down the time they take, you'll be saving companies a ton of money.

If you are doing something twice, you can probably automate it.

You can use the Amazon Nova Act playground to generate scripts to automate all of these tasks:

1. Go to the Amazon Nova Act playground
2. Describe what you want in plain English
3. Test it in the playground
4. Download the Python script that it generates
5. Customize it if necessary in your IDE
6. Deploy it

You can also integrate your automations with a human-in-the-loop step so you can intervene when judgment is required, such as solving a CAPTCHA or completing an authentication flow.

Here's what this looks like in practice:

1. Hertz, the car rental company, automated manual test cases for their core rental flow. They say this accelerated their shipping velocity by 5x.

2. Alvee Health automated its public benefits enrollment process. They expect this to increase the number of successful benefit registrations by 30%.

3. PGA Tour automated its test suite to cover multiple geographies and time zones.

There's a huge opportunity right now to identify all the tasks we constantly do and automate them one by one.

Here is a link to the Nova Act playground: https://t.co/5RFN5TX0A8

Thanks to Amazon for sponsoring this post.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Svpino promotes automating boring repetitive tasks as undervalued opportunity - discusses Amazon Nova Act for automating tests, forms, checkout flows with real examples from Hertz, Alvee Health, PGA Tour
items.reasoning: Sponsored content but provides practical AI automation guidance with concrete use cases. Legitimate value despite sponsorship (19K views)

I keep thinking of this term in my head because it's so good

"Shotgun to Sniper Strategy"

@marclou coined it

You want to start with a shotgun strategy where you try lots of ideas, launch lots of projects, MVPs etc. add a Stripe buy button to everything

Then see what really gets traction, goes viral, makes money (!) and then what keeps making money over time (like months)

Then you wanna sniper and focus on that project to make it big

items.title: Spotify launched in 2008, and despite having had all this time to make a great product, it still can...
items.content:
Spotify launched in 2008, and despite having had all this time to make a great product, it still cannot generate a good quality infinite personalized playlist.

Yet it's so simple to do. Just play the user's liked songs, and once in a while, play a song that isn't in the user's playlist but is among the top 100 songs played by other users right after this liked song.

How hard is that to implement, @Spotify?

items.summary: Critique of Spotify's recommendation algorithm - suggests simple collaborative filtering approach for infinite personalized playlists that hasn't been implemented after 16+ years
items.reasoning: Interesting critique of recommendation systems from ML author, good engagement, practical observation

items.title:
We actually do shotgun to sniper in life all the time

In dating you go on dates with different peop...
items.content:
We actually do shotgun to sniper in life all the time

In dating you go on dates with different people to find a match, then when you find them you double down

In getting a job you apply to lots of companies, then when you get the job you focus on that

Digital nomading essentially is it too, you try many places to live to find one or a few to settle for longer

So people are focusing on a single business or project with zero traction and zero revenue and zero customers for many years is logically wrong in most cases
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: Levelsio argues 'shotgun to sniper' strategy applies broadly in life - dating, job hunting, digital nomading - criticizing focusing on zero-traction projects for years
items.reasoning: High engagement (81K views). Business strategy applicable to AI/tech startups but generic advice

items.title:
I asked Grok: What is cherry picking?

The answer:

**Cherry picking** refers to the practice of sel...
items.content:
I asked Grok: What is cherry picking?

The answer:

**Cherry picking** refers to the practice of selectively choosing data, evidence, examples, or items that support a particular position or desired outcome, while ignoring or suppressing those that contradict it.

This term originates from the idea of harvesting cherries: a picker selects only the ripest, best ones, leading an observer to mistakenly assume all the fruit on the tree is equally good.

### Primary Meanings
1. **As a Logical Fallacy (Most Common in Arguments and Data Analysis)**:  
   Known as the *fallacy of incomplete evidence*, *suppressed evidence*, or *card stacking*. It involves presenting only favorable evidence to persuade others, creating a biased or misleading impression.  
   This is often linked to confirmation bias and is common in debates, science denial (e.g., climate change or evolution), politics, and media.  
   **Example**: A climate skeptic highlights a few cold winter days to argue against global warming, ignoring long-term temperature data and scientific consensus showing rising trends.

2. **Neutral or Positive Selection**:  
   To carefully choose the best or most desirable items from a group (e.g., "cherry-pick the top talent from applicants" or "cherry-pick stocks based on performance").  
   Dictionaries like Merriam-Webster and Cambridge define it this way, sometimes noting it can feel unfair if it disadvantages others.

3. **Technical Uses**:  
   - In Git (version control software): "Cherry-picking" a commit means applying changes from a specific commit on one branch to another, without merging everything.  
   - In sports (e.g., basketball): Positioning near the opponent's goal to wait for an easy scoring opportunity.

In everyday discussion, especially around arguments, statistics, or debates, "cherry picking" usually carries a negative connotation, implying intellectual dishonesty or bias. To avoid it, consider all relevant evidence for a balanced view.
items.author: @KirkDBorne
items.summary: Kirk Borne shares Grok's detailed explanation of 'cherry picking' as a logical fallacy, including definitions, examples, and technical uses.

items.title:
Yes about 1.5cm thick ribeye

Deep frozen

Put in airfryer, add some beef tallow or ghee, add salt p...
items.content:
Yes about 1.5cm thick ribeye

Deep frozen

Put in airfryer, add some beef tallow or ghee, add salt pepper onto the tallow or ghee it will spread it

Then 10min

Then after 10min flip and probably another 5min but monitor a lot

You wanna have it brown outside pink inside

Why not room temperature (like when you cook in a frying pan)?

Because room temperature steak will be brown outside and gray inside in an airfryer

The frozen part is perfect because it takes more time to cook the inside than the outside so outside will be brown and inside pink

Also deep freezing steak I imagine helps kill any live bacteria left
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: Levelsio shares detailed frozen steak air fryer cooking method, including food safety reasoning about bacteria.
items.reasoning: Off-topic cooking post despite high engagement (91k views). Not AI/ML relevant.

Just a chill guy
